1.title: "Manga Series Maison Ikkoku Translated" p. 35 in The Comics Journal, no. 158
1.author: [No author]

2.heading: Manga Shakespeare.
2.title: As You Like It
2.author: adapted by Richard Appignanesi ; illustrated by Chie Kutsuwada.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): Banished to the Forest of Arden, Rosalind, disguised as a boy, reunites with true love Orlando.

3.heading: Manga Shakespeare.
3.title: Hamlet
3.author: by William Shakespeare ; illustrated by Emma Vieceli ; text adaptor, Richard Appignanesi.
notes: "Hamlet is one of Shakespeare's most well-known plays, and this exciting new retelling provides young readers an innovative introduction to "the melancholy Dane." Hamlet is your typical angst-ridden teen-he doesn't know how to deal with his responsibilities, how to treat his girlfriend, or how to react to his father's death. He has no one to trust, and he even acts crazy so adults will leave him alone."
Alternative genre, takes place in 2107 A.D.

4.heading: Manga Shakespeare.
4.title: Henry VIII
4.author: adapted by Richard Appignanesi ; illustrated by Patrick Warren.

5.heading: Manga Shakespeare.
5.title: Julius Caesar
5.author: William Shakespeare ; text adaptor, Richard Appignanesi ; illustrated by Mustashrik.
notes: "Orignaly published in the U.K. by SelfMadeHero."

Summary (from SkyRiver): A graphic adaptation of William Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar" in which Cassius, fearing Julius Caesar's ambition, forms a conspiracy among Roman republicans to assassinate him on the Ides of March.

6.heading: Manga Shakespeare.
6.title: King Lear
6.author: adapted by Richard Appignanesi ; illustrated by Ilya.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): Shakespeare's tragedy of a royal father and his daughters is presented scene by scene in comic book format.

7.heading: Manga Shakespeare.
7.title: Macbeth
7.author: text adaptor, Richard Appignanesi ; illustrated by Robert Deas.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): Retells Shakespeare's play about a man who kills his king after hearing the prophesies of three witches.

8.heading: Manga Shakespeare.
8.title: The Merchant of Venice
8.author: adapted by Richard Appignanesi ; illustrated by Faye Yong.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): In sixteenth-century Venice, when a merchant must default on a large loan from an abused Jewish moneylender for a friend with romantic ambitions, the vengeful creditor demands a gruesome payment instead.

9.heading: Manga Shakespeare.
9.title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
9.author: illustrated by Kate Brown ; adaptor, Richard Appignanesi.
notes: "Originally published in the U.K. by SelfMadeHero."
Summary (from SkyRiver): Fairies create unexpected love triangles among a group of teenagers.

10.heading: Manga Shakespeare.
10.title: Much Ado About Nothing
10.author: adapted by Richard Appignanesi ; illustrated by Emma Vieceli.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): A comic book version of Shakespeare's comedy about mistaken identities, games, eavesdropping, and unrequited love.

11.heading: Manga Shakespeare.
11.title: Othello
11.author: adapted by Richard Appignanesi ; illustrated by Ryuta Osada.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): When Othello's fellow soldier Iago starts filling his head with rumors of his wife Desdemona's infidelity, Othello begins down the path of his own destruction.

12.heading: Manga Shakespeare.
12.title: Richard III
12.author: adapted by Richard Appignanesi ; illustrated by Patrick Warren.

13.heading: Manga Shakespeare.
13.title: Romeo and Juliet
13.author: by William Shakespeare ; adapted by Richard Appignanesi ; illustrated by Sonia Leong.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): In comics format, an adaptation of Shakespeare's classic tale about two star-crossed lovers.

14.heading: Manga Shakespeare.
14.title: The Tempest
14.author: illustrated by Paul Duffield ; adaptor, Richard Appignanesi.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): An adaptation of Shakespeare's tale about the wizard Prospero, whose daughter Miranda teaches him a lesson in forgiveness when he seeks vengeance against his enemies.

15.heading: Manga Shakespeare.
15.title: Twelfth Night
15.author: adapted by Richard Appignanesi ; illustrated by Nana Li.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): Retells, in comic book format, Shakespeare's comedy about Viola who, upon finding herself shipwrecked, pretends to be a servant but finds herself falling in love with Duke Orsino.

"Originally published as G.I. Joe: Future Noir issues #1-2."
Science fiction genre, about special forces.

65.heading: Manga Style Comic Books, Strips, Etc.--Technique.
65.title: Mangaquest : Join the Adventure and Learn How to Draw It
65.author: Ben Gibson & Serge Marcos.
notes: Summary (from Skyriver): A comic book story provides the base for this how-to-draw mangabook, in which an aspiring manga artist, or manga-ka, is instructed in the art of drawing humanoids, different types of creatures, and mecha and other technology in the style of Japanese manga.

66.heading: Manga Style Comic Books, Strips, Etc.--Technique.
66.title: Mega Manga : the Complete Reference to Drawing Manga
66.author: Keith Sparrow.

67.heading: Manga Style Comic Books, Strips, Etc.--Technique.
67.title: The Monster Book of Manga : Boys
67.author: edited by Ikari Studio.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): Illustrations and tutorials on how to draw male manga characters, from the everyday boy to the ninja warrior.

68.heading: Manga Style Comic Books, Strips, Etc.--Technique.
68.title: The Monster Book of Manga : Draw like the Experts
68.author: Estudio Joso.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): From comic illustration Studio Joso comes the ultimate guide on how to draw manga. "The Monster Book of Manga" is divided into sections focusing on the most popular manga figures and themes-Girls, Boys, Samurai, Monsters, and Computer. Each illustration is broken down into six stages accompanied by step-by-step instructions, taking the artist from an initial black-and-white sketch to the final color piece. They're also accompanied by practical suggestions, hints, and tips.

69.heading: Manga Style Comic Books, Strips, Etc.--Technique.
69.title: The Monster Book of Manga : Fairies and Magical Creatures
69.author: edited by Ikari Studio.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): Breaks down the illustration process into six key stages, in a step-by-step guide that provides hints and tricks for how to draw a wide variety of fairy and magical creature subjects in manga style.
Translation of: Manga Paso a Paso.

70.heading: Manga Style Comic Books, Strips, Etc.--Technique.
70.title: The Monster Book of Manga : Girls
70.author: edited by Ikari Studio.
notes: Book about drawing women and girls.

71.title: Manga Style Comic Books, Strips, Etc.
71.author: [No author]

contents.author: Irene Flores.
contents.title: Technique., Shojo Fashion Manga Art School : How to Draw Cool Looks and Characters

notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): Create fabulous shojo manga clothing and characters with different looks, primarily in pencil and ink. Loaded with techniques and tips from an exciting young artist, this book demonstrates the Japanese comic-book practices of stylized proportions, clean lines and contrast between black and white (manga are usually published in black and white), with some finished art in color.

72.heading: Manga Style Comic Books, Strips, Etc.--Technique.
72.title: Shonen Art Studio : Everything You Need to Create Your Own Shonen Manga Comics
72.author: Yishan Li ; with Yishan Studio and Andrew James.
notes: "This ultimate guide, with its accompanying CD, includes everything you need to make your own gutsy, action-packed shonen manga. Covering topics such as creating an interesting story line or concept, writing simple but compelling dialogue, creating dynamic black-and-white manga pages, and impressive color covers, this is the first book to distill all the elements of shonen manga into one easy-to-use package".
Techniques for creating adventure story comics.

95.heading: Manga University Culinary Institute.
95.title: The Manga Cookbook
95.author: presented by the Manga University Culinary Institute, with recipes by Yoko Ishihara ; illustrated by Chihiro Hattori.
notes: "Reading manga sure can make a person hungry! Food appears frequently in Japanese comics, but what exactly is it that the characters are eating? Introducing The Manga Cookbook, an illustrated step-by-step guide to preparing simple Japanese dishes using ingredients found in every Western kitchen. Learn to identify and make the same things you see in all your favorite manga: authentic onigiri (rice balls), yakitori (skewered chicken), oshinko (pickled vegetables), udon (Japanese noodles), okonomiyaki (Japanese-style pizza) and many others! Includes sections on how to assemble bento boxed lunches and properly use chopsticks. Features original manga illustrations by Chihiro Hattori."

132.title: "Mangal Pande : He Fired the First Shot"
132.author: script, Toni Patel ; illustrations, Souren Roy ; editor, Anant Pai
132.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 675 (1985, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "The Indian sepoys of the Native Infantry Regiment, in Barrackpore, were appalled when they heard that the cartridges they bit into before loading their guns were going to be greased with cow and pig fat. It was an insult to their religious sentiments. The murmurings of dissent rose as the news spread but the British were insensitive to the reasons behind it. And then Mangal Pandey, a sepoy from the Native Infantry, fired the shot that triggered of the First War of Indian Independence."

133.heading: MangaLand.
133.title: Japanese in MangaLand : learning the basics
133.author: Marc Bernabe ; illustrations, Ken Niimura.
notes: Summary (from OCLC): Learn written and spoken Japanese through the popular comics or "mangas". Includes concise lessons with practical exercises and a mini-guidebook of the 160 essential kanji characters.

134.heading: MangaLand.
134.title: Japanese in MangaLand 2 : Basic to Intermediate Level

136.title: The Mangalicious Tick : the Rise of the Setting Sun.
136.author: [No author]

137.heading: Mangalvedha.
137.title: "Chokha Mela : the Boy Who Heard God"
137.author: script, Kamala Chandrakant ; illustrations, Dilip Kadam ; editor, Anant Pai
137.appears_in: p. 1-29 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 744 (1983, 2009 printing).
notes: Begins: "One evening towards the close of the thirteenth century, a few Mahar boys were playing hututu outside their huts at Mangalvedha in Solapur district."

Summary from back cover: "Chokha was a young boy when he first heard the call of the Lord. But all attempts to enter temples were thwarted by those who only saw him as a Mahar, an untouchable. However, Chokha's devotion was such that his heart became a temple, and he sang with purity and complete faith. Chokha Mela's Abhangs or verses echo to this day around the temples of Maharashtra."

138.title: Mangaman
138.author: by Barry Lyga ; illustrated by Colleen Doran.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): Ryoko Kiyama, a character from a Japanese comic book, or manga, falls through a rip into the real world
and tries to survive as the ultimate outsider at a typical American high school.
